A series of left-to-right inequivalent 1,3-disubstituted benzimidazolium halide pro-ligands having the general formula [RBNHCCH2OxMe][X] (R = 3-Me-Bn, 3,5-Me2-Bn, 2,4,6-Me3-Bn, 2,3,5,6-Me4-Bn, 2,3,4,5,6-Me5-Bn, 3,4,5-(OMe)3-Bn, or 4-tBu-Bn; X = Cl, Br) were synthesized by the alkylation of 1-((3-methyloxetan-3-yl)methyl)benzimidazole. The corresponding Ag complexes, (RBNHCCH2OxMe)AgX, were prepared following pro-ligand addition to Ag2O. These compounds were characterized using spectroscopic techniques such as FT-IR, NMR spectroscopy, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The solid-state structure of (3-Me-BnBNHCCH2OxMe)AgCl revealed a linear monomer while [(2,4,6-Me3-BnBNHCCH2OxMe)AgCl]2 was found to exist as a dimer with pseudo trigonal planar geometry about each metal center. The synthesized (RBNHCCH2OxMe)AgX complexes were found to be efficient for the addition of carbon dioxide to epoxides to yield value-added cyclic carbonates at ambient pressure. Amongst the investigated complexes, the bimetallic complex [(2,4,6-Me3-BnBNHCCH2OxMe)AgCl]2 was found to be the most active for CO2 insertion, exhibiting favorable activity when compared to known NHC complexes. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Carbon dioxide insertion N-heterocyclic carbene Silver complexes Cyclic carbonate Homogeneous catalysis 1 Introduction The growing discharge of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere is responsible for global warming and its associated ecological concerns. Carbon capture and storage (CCS) is a critical approach to averting global warming, but the overall cost of currently available CCS technologies is still exorbitant for their large-scale deployment [1]. Carbon dioxide is released into the atmosphere as a result of the combustion of fossil fuels (coal, natural gas, and oil), solid waste, trees, and other biological materials, as well as chemical processes (e.g., the manufacture of cement). When plants absorb carbon dioxide as part of the biological carbon cycle, it is removed from the atmosphere (or "sequestered"). Despite the remote chance that global shutdowns during the pandemic would provide some relief from the climate issue, new evidence indicates that there is no such silver lining. In reality, newly released measurements of atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2) levels show that this heat-trapping molecule has soared to record levels not seen by experts in the contemporary age. Researchers from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) recently recorded an atmospheric CO2 concentration of 419.13 parts per million (ppm) [2]. At the same time, CO2 can be thought of as an abundant, cheap, non-toxic, and renewable C1 reserve. The transformation of CO2 into economically valuable products is receiving significant attention from chemists [3]. Furthermore, the production of five-membered cyclic carbonates via epoxide cycloaddition is an atom economical way to utilize CO2 [4–8]. These carbonates can serve as aprotic solvents, electrolytes for lithium-ion batteries, fuel additives, synthetic intermediates, and materials for engineering plastics. The creation of α-alkylidene cyclic carbonates from the addition of CO2 to propargylic alcohols also allows for widespread applications in the organic synthesis [9]. Homogeneous catalysts featuring Al [10–13], Mg [14], Zn [15,16], Cr [17,18] and Co[19–21], as well as heterogeneous metal oxides[22], metal carbonates [23], molecular sieves [24], metal-organic frameworks [25–27], ion-exchange resins [28], nanoparticles [3,29], functionalized polymers [30], biopolymer-supported catalysts [31]. Tungstate ionic liquids [32] and ionic liquids [33] have been reported to mediate the cycloaddition of CO2 and epoxides [34]. Silver catalysts have proven to be particularly useful for this purpose. For example, Cetinkaya and coworkers reported that (NHC)Ag complexes can catalyze the cycloaddition of CO2 to terminal epoxides at 120 °C and 20 bar of pressure [35]. Furthermore, Chen, Gan, and Yi demonstrated that treating neat alkyl-substituted terminal epoxides with CO2 (1 atm) in the presence of the dinuclear silver complex [Ag2(PDP)]OTf yielded functionalized carbonates in good to high yields at ambient temperature [36]. Epoxides featuring an aryl group, on the other hand, did not react well in this reaction. NHCs are widely used as effective ligands in coordination chemistry because they are strong σ-donors and weak π-acceptors that are easy to access, inexpensive, and air-stable [37–42]. NHCs make a strong metal-carbon bond with various metals. Therefore, metal-NHC complexes are used as robust, reactive, and selective catalysts in many chemical reactions. Initially, metal-NHC complexes were used extensively for CC, CN, and CH bond activation reactions [43–47]. Recently, 1,2-disubstituted benzimidazole-supported zinc complexes have been applied as catalysts for the cycloaddition of CO2 and epoxides at a high pressure of 30 bar [48,49]. Also, alkoxide-functionalized imidazolium betaines [50], porous silver coordination polymers, and CNTS supported N-heterocyclic carbene complexes [51,52] have been reported as catalysts for this reaction at high pressure. In this work, we report new NHC-benzimidazole (BNHC) silver complexes as excellent catalysts for the chemical fixation of CO2 into epoxides at ambient pressure to generate carbonates without the need of solvent or cocatalyst. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Design, synthesis, and characterization of ligands and complexes Steric hindrance plays a vital role in catalysis and can promote reductive elimination pathways. In this study, we sought to design (BNHC)Ag complexes featuring an aryl group that could be tuned to control steric hindrance. A methyl-oxetane containing benzimidazolium as a second ligand was included; the methyl substituent provides some lipophilicity increasing the solubility of the complexes in non-polar solvents while the oxetane part introduces more polarity and hence increases the solubility in polar solvents [53]. The ring strain of oxetane also renders the oxygen more susceptible to hydrogen bonding interactions which lead to increased solubility in polar solvents (Fig. 1 ). [54] The synthetic methodologies used to prepare pro-ligands and complexes are summarized in Schemes 1 and 2 . Pro-ligands of the general formula [RBNHCCH2OxMe][X] (1a–1g) were prepared in high yield (> 88%) in a single step by the reaction of 1-((3-methyloxetan-3-yl)methyl)benzimidazole with various aryl halides in a 1:1 ratio. DMF or toluene was used as a solvent at a temperature range between 80 and 100 °C for 36 h. The [BNHC][X] salts were then treated with Ag2O to prepare the respective Ag complexes, (RBNHCCH2OxMe)AgX (2a–2g), following one of two approaches. First, the general procedure reported by Wang and Lin was applied [55]. This procedure involves reacting a benzimidazolium halide pro-ligand (1 Equiv.) with Ag2O (1 Equiv.) in DCM at room temperature for 24 h. The second procedure, employed for 2 g, involved adding the same reactants to chloroform and heating to 50 °C for 12 h. Compounds 2a–2g were obtained as white crystalline solids in high yield. All the pro-ligands were air, light, and moisture stable as solids and in solution. However, 2a–2g were light-sensitive, so the complexation reaction was carried out in an Al-foil-covered flask. These complexes could be easily stored on the shelf and are soluble in common organic solvents including DMF, DCM, chloroform, ethanol, and acetonitrile. These compounds are not soluble in hydrocarbons and ethers. Therefore, solvent mixtures were used for recrystallization, such as DCM: ether (1:3) and DCM: n-pentane (1:3). The synthesized [BNHC][X] (1a–1g) and silver complexes (2a–2g) were fully characterized by NMR (1H, 13C) and FT-IR spectroscopy. The solid-state structures of 2a and 2c were also determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The infrared spectra of the synthesized pro-ligands (1a–1g) featured an intense υ(C=N) band between 1550 and 1560 cm−1. The infrared spectra of complexes 2a–2g did not display a peak in that region. Rather, the υ(CN) stretches of complexes 2a–2g were located between 1450 and 1480 cm−1. The 1H NMR spectra of [BNHC][X] salts 1a–1g in CDCl3 featured an intense singlet at 12.18, 11.69, 11.47, 11.25, 12.18, 12.14, and 11.81 ppm, respectively, assigned to the BNHC imino proton. Critically, signals attributable to the imino NH resonance of the starting material were absent. The 13C NMR spectra of 1a–1g exhibited a peak at 144.4, 144.4, 144.2, 144.1, and 144.6. 144.4 and 143.6 ppm, respectively, which is assigned to the BNHC imino-carbon. In general, silver carbene carbon peaks appear in this downfield region of the spectrum, but exceptions exist due to the fluxional solution behavior [56–58]. In the solid-state structure of 2a (Fig. 2 a, Table 1 ), Ag is coordinated to the BNHC C-atom and one Cl atom in a nearly linear alinement. The Ag-C and Ag-Cl bond lengths were found to be 2.086(4) and 2.3142(13) Å, respectively, whereas the Cl-Ag-C bond angle was determined to be 174.36(11)°. The oxetane group A (C1-C3/O1), benzimidazole group B (C6-C12/N1/N2) and p-xylene group C (C13-C20) are planar with a root mean square (r.m.s.) deviation of 0.0745, 0.0180, and 0.0275 Å, respectively. The two C-atoms (C4/C5) directly attached to group A are at 1.0244 (9) and -1.4746 (7) Å, respectively. The dihedral angles between A/B, A/C, and B/C are 34.13 (2)°, 52.11 (2)°, and 79.7 (7)°, respectively. The molecules are connected through CH…O, CH…Cl bonding, as shown in Fig. 3 and Table 2 . In addition to these H-bonding interactions, π…π stacking is found between the imidazole ring (C6/C7/C12/N1/N2) of benzimidazole moiety and the benzene ring (C14-C19) with a distance of 3.989(3) Å. There is also a ring offset of 1.490 Å. This interaction helps to further stabilize crystal packing. Similarly, the phenyl ring (C7–C12) of a molecule located at the asymmetric unit is found to engage with the phenyl ring (C14-C19) of a symmetry-related molecule at 1-x,1/2 + y,1/2-z. The inter-centroid separation and ring offset for this interaction are found to be 4.283(3) and 2.191 Å, respectively. Symmetry codes: (i) −x, y + 1/2, −z + 1/2; (ii) −x, y−1/2, −z + 1/2; (iii) −x + 1/2, −y + 1, z−1/2; (iv) −x + 1, y + 1/2, −z + 1/2. In 2c (Fig. 2b, Table 1), half of the molecule is generated by inversion to form a dimer (e.g., Cl1/Cl1i; Ag1/Ag1i). A dichloromethane solvent molecule, which is refined with an occupancy of 50% for each atom, is also present. The oxetane moiety A (C1-C3/O1), 1-methylbenzimidazole moiety B (C5-C12/N1/N2), and 1-(2,4,6-trimethylbenzyl) benzimidazole group C (C13–C22) is found to be roughly planar with an r.m.s. deviation of 0.0615, 0.0178, and 0.0313 Å, respectively. The dihedral angles between A/B, A/C, and B/C are 74.18 (1)°, 74.34 (1)°, and 89.20 (4)°, respectively. The molecules are connected through C-H…Cl and C-H…O bonding to form an infinite zigzag chain along the crystallographic a-axis, as shown in Fig. 4 and specified in Table 3 . In addition, a CH…π interaction exists, which helps in further stabilization of the crystal packing. The geometrical parameters of this C-H…π interaction are specified in Table 3. Symmetry codes: (i) −x, −y, −z; (ii) −x + 1/2, y + 1/2, −z + 1/2; (iii) −x−1/2, y + 1/2, −z + 1/2; (iv) x + 1/2, y−1/2, −z + 1/2; (v) x + 1, y + 1, z + 1; (iii) −x + 1/2, y−1/2, −z + 1/2. Cg (1), Cg(2), Cg(3) are centroid of (Ag1/Cl1/Ag1i/Cl1i), (C1-C3/O1), (C14-C17/C19/C20) rings, respectively. 2.2 Catalytic cycloaddition of CO2 and epoxides The newly characterized (BNHC)Ag complexes 2a-g were subsequently utilized for CO2 insertion into epichlorohydrin as a model substrate under solvent-free conditions in the absence of cocatalyst. As a control experiment, the precursor P1, which was used to prepare pro-ligands 1a–1g, was tested separately. In this case, a low yield of 5% was detected, even after a prolonged reaction time of 24 h (entry 1, Table 1). In sharp contrast, complex 2a allowed for 90% conversion to cyclic carbonate with high selectivity after 12 h. Then, the effects of temperature (entries 2–6, Table 4 ) and benzimidazolium side-chain substitution (entries 7–12, Table 4) were studied. Due to the excellent catalytic activity of the test reaction of catalyst 2a at ambient pressure (entry 2, Table 4), no further pressure effect was investigated. Epichlorohydrin was also selected as a model substrate for these reactions. First, to obtain the maximum possible formation of the desired cyclic carbonate product, the temperature was optimized (entries 3–6, Table 4). At ambient temperature (entry 3, Table 4), no conversion of the substrate was obtained using complex 2a as a catalyst after 12 h. In contrast, a sharp increase in conversion was seen upon increasing temperature. Specifically, elevating the temperate from 100 to 120 °C resulted in an abrupt increase in conversion (entries 4–6 and 2, Table 4). Therefore, 120 °C was set as the optimized temperature for additional trials. Then, catalysts 2b-g were tested under the optimized reaction conditions (i.e., 120 °C and ambient pressure) and their activity for CO2/epoxide cycloaddition was compared. Complexes (2b-2e) with two, three, four, or five methyl groups on the benzyl side chain of the benzimidazolium ligand were investigated. The catalytic results are displayed in Table 4, entries 7-12. The data revealed the following catalytic order; 2a < 2b < 2g < 2d < 2e < 2f < 2c. This trend suggests that increasing the number of methyl substituents on the benzimidazolium moiety promotes cyclic organic carbonate formation. The introduction of three methoxy substituents on the benzimidazolium ligand was studied and the catalytic results for 2f, (entry 11, Table 4) suggest a decent and even comparable catalytic performance to 2c. This result suggests that enhanced electron donation from the spectator ligand (NHC) leads to better catalytic performance. In addition, both the resonance and inductive effect can stabilize the Ag3+ oxidation state during the course of the reaction. The bimetallic silver precatalyst 2c was selected as the best catalyst in the current study and its performance was then examined for several substrates to check the scope of the catalyst. Epoxides having different aliphatic and aromatic side chains, with their respective electron-donating and electron-withdrawing substituents, were coupled with CO2 to evaluate the robustness and utility of the catalyst. Fortunately, all tested epoxides were successfully converted to their respective carbonates with high selectivity and yield at ambient pressure (Table 5 ). For each example in Table 5, a turnover number (TON) of 990 has been achieved along with turnover frequencies (TOFs) at reaction completion of 82.5 h−1 at 120 °C. Reaction conditions: All reactions were conducted without solvent and co-catalyst. Pressure 1 bar, 120 °C, 12 h, 0.1 mol% catalyst loading, 13.48 mmol substrate. Conversions were based on 1H NMR and isolated yield provided in parenthesis (selectivity > 99% in all cases). A comparison of the most active catalyst (2c) with other reported (NHC)Ag catalysts is displayed in Table 6 . Complex 2c appears to be the most effective (NHC)Ag catalyst in terms of catalyst loading (0.1 mol %) and CO2 pressure (1 bar). Most literature reports that utilize (NHC)Ag catalysts describe carbon dioxide cycloaddition to propargyl alcohols [59,60]. Relatively few reports of carbon dioxide coupling with epoxides. Hence, this appears to be the first report that uses NHC-coordinated Ag complexes for the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides at ambient pressure without using a co-catalyst or solvent. We note that our catalysts operate at a higher temperature than the bispyridylpyrrole catalyst, [Ag2(PDP)] OTf [35]. 2.3 Reaction mechanism A tentative mechanism for the cycloaddition of CO2 and epoxide using 2c is depicted in Fig. 5 . This Ag pre-catalyst is likely to exist as a monomer in solution (a) which can oxidatively add epichlorohydrin to generate an Ag(ⅡⅠ) complex (b). Intermediate b would likely have a square planar geometry similar to known Ag(ⅡⅠ) complexes [66,67]. This phenomenon of Ag(III) formation was further confirmed by 1H NMR spectroscopy upon reacting 2c and epichlorohydrin in a 1:1 ratio and monitoring the reaction between 0.5 and 12 h at 120 °C. As the reaction proceeds, the ECH peaks start disappearing at 0.5, 3, and 6 h and completely vanish after 12 h while the peaks of intermediate b grow in and become dominant (Supporting Information, Fig. S47). These results suggest that the formation of intermediate b is slow and likely to be the rate-determining step. Notably, the electron-donating NHC spectator ligand appears to generate and stabilize the Ag(ⅡⅠ) oxidation state. Furthermore, we added an excess of CO2 to 2c in the presence of chloroform-d to investigate the binding of CO2 to 2c. However, we did not observe a reaction by NMR spectroscopy. In the second step, insertion of CO2 takes place to generate intermediate c. This intermediate could not be observed by NMR spectroscopy, suggesting that reductive elimination leads to fast ring closure and cyclic carbonate formation [68]. 3 Conclusion A series of benzimidazolium halides (1a-g) and their respective benzimidazolium N-heterocyclic carbene Ag complexes (2a-g) were successfully prepared. After characterizing the silver complexes using various physicochemical techniques and elucidating their structure by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, these complexes were applied to the cycloaddition of CO2 and epoxides at atmospheric pressure without a co-catalyst to test their synthetic utility. The (BNHC)Ag complexes were found to be more effective than previously reported NHC catalysts for this transformation. Furthermore, benzimidazolium side-chain modification was found to enhance the catalytic activity of the corresponding silver complexes, allowing for turnover frequencies of 82.5 h−1 at 120 °C. 4 Experimental section 4.1 General considerations All chemicals, including epoxides, were purchased from Aladdin and Sigma-Aldrich and used without any further purification unless otherwise stated. An inert environment was created by using argon or nitrogen gas. Open capillary tubes were used in the Electrothermal 9200 melting point apparatus to analyze the synthesized compounds' melting point. Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) spectra were recorded on Perkin-Elmer Spectrum 100 spectrometer ranging from 4000 to 400 cm−1. NMR spectra of the compounds were obtained from Bruker AscendTM 400 Avance III HD (500 MHz or 400 MHz (1H) and 100 MHz (13C)) CDCl3 and DMSO-d 6 were used as NMR solvents. 4.2 General synthetic procedure for starting precursor (P1) A suspension of NaH (1mmol, 60% in mineral oil) in THF (50 mL) was slowly (portion-wise) added to a 100 mL flask that was previously charged with benzimidazole (1 mmol). After complete addition, the reaction was stirred at ambient temperature for 1 h. The suspension was mixed with 3-(chloromethyl)-3-methyloxetane (1.1 mmol) and allowed to reflux for 24 h. After that, the reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature and the THF solvent was evaporated in vacuo. The resulting gel was dissolved in DCM (30 mL), and the solution was filtered. It was concentrated to 10 mL and ether (20 mL) was added to promote precipitation. The product was obtained as a crystalline solid. 4.2.1 1-((3-methyloxetan-3-yl) methyl) benzimidazole (P1) Yield: 94%; White solid: mp 108-109 °C. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ (ppm): 7.89 (s, 1H, H NC H N ), 7.82 (dd, J = 6.9, 1.6 Hz, 1H, H Ar), 7.42 (dd, J = 7.0, 1.6 Hz, 1H, H Ar), 7.37 – 7.24 (m, 2H, H Ar), 4.64 (d, J = 6.3 Hz, 2H, H C H 2), 4.43 (d, J = 5.0 Hz, 4H, H ( O ( C H 2 ) 2), 1.34 (s, 3H, H C H 3) 13C NMR (CDCl3, 101 MHz) δ (ppm): 143.5 C (N C HN), 143.1, 134.5, 123.3, 122.3, 120.6, 109.6, 80.3, 51.6, 41.5, 22.2. Dry nitrogen was re-added to the flask and the reaction was heated for 2 days at 100 °C after the addition of DMF (5 mL) or toluene (5 mL) as a solvent. Method 1: A suspension of benzimidazolium salt (1.0 mmol) and Ag2O (1.0 mmol) in dichloromethane (20 mL) was stirred at room temperature for 1 week. The resulting reaction mixture was first filtered through Celite, followed by the removal of the solvent under reduced pressure. The crude product was recrystallized from dichloromethane/diethyl ether (1:2 v/v). Method 2: A suspension of benzimidazolium salt (1.0 mmol) and Ag2O (2.2 mmol) in chloroform (20 mL) was stirred at 50 °C for 24 h. The resulting mixture was filtered through Celite, followed by the removal of the solvent under reduced pressure. The crude product was recrystallized from chloroform/diethyl ether (1:2 v/v). 4.4.1 Chloro[(1-(4-methylbenzyl)-3-((3-methyloxetan-3-yl)methyl)benzimidazole-2-ylidene]silver(I) (2a) Yield: 62 %; White solid: mp 181-182 °C, 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ (ppm): 7.48 (d, J = 8.1 Hz, 1H, H Ar), 7.43–7.30 (m, 3H, H Ar), 7.14 (q, J = 8.2 Hz, 4H, H Ar), 5.61 (s, 2H, H C H 2), 4.82 (d, J = 6.3 Hz, 2H, H ( O ( C H 2 ) 2 )), 4.37 (d, J = 6.3 Hz, 2H, H ( O ( C H 2 ) 2 )), 4.68 (s, 2H, H C H 2), 2.31 (s, 3H, H C H 3), 1.47 (s, 3H, H C H 3). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3) δ (ppm): 138.5, 134.7, 133.5, 131.7, 129.8, 127.1, 124.4, 124.3, 112.4, 111.7, 80.2, 54.9, 53.4, 41.4, 23.3, 21.1. Bruker Kappa APEXII CCD X-ray diffractometer was used to record X-ray diffraction data of the complexes at room temperature. The ω-scan method was applied for this method in which graphite-monochromatic Mo Kα radiation was passed. APEX-II software was used for the collection of data and cell refinement [69]. while absorption correction was performed using SADABS software [70]. Direct methods of SHEXS-97 were used to solve the structure of the compounds [71]. Refinement was done by full-matrix least-squares calculations on F 2 via SHELXL-2018/3 [72]. Hydrogen atoms were placed in perfect positions and the riding model was used to preserve by fixing the bond lengths of CH3, CH2, and CH at 0.96, 0.97, and 0.93Å, respectively. The displacement parameters of the H atoms were fixed at U iso(H) = 1.2U eq (1.5U eq for CH3). Finally, ORTEP-3 [73], PLATON [73] and Mercury [74] software were used to generate the molecular graphics of new compounds [75]. 4.6 Carbon dioxide insertion into epoxides A 30 mL stainless steel autoclave containing a magnetic stirrer dipped into an oil bath was used for the CO2/coupling reaction. The desired amount of Ag catalyst and the respective epoxide was charged into the autoclave, flushed three times with CO2 at room temperature and the reaction mixture was stirred continuously under 1 bar CO2 pressure for the required period of reaction time. Small samples from the reaction mixtures, after cooling the reaction mixture to room temperature, were taken and a 1H NMR analysis of the crude product was achieved. The isolated yield of the product was obtained by flash chromatography through the solvent mixture of n-hexane: ethyl acetate (1:3), while chloroform or DCM eluted the complex. coredata.dc:description: A series of left-to-right inequivalent 1,3-disubstituted benzimidazolium halide pro-ligands having the general formula [RBNHCCH2OxMe][X] (R = 3-Me-Bn, 3,5-Me2-Bn, 2,4,6-Me3-Bn, 2,3,5,6-Me4-Bn, 2,3,4,5,6-Me5-Bn, 3,4,5-(OMe)3-Bn, or 4-tBu-Bn; X = Cl, Br) were synthesized by the alkylation of 1-((3-methyloxetan-3-yl)methyl)benzimidazole. The corresponding Ag complexes, (RBNHCCH2OxMe)AgX, were prepared following pro-ligand addition to Ag2O. These compounds were characterized using spectroscopic techniques such as FT-IR, NMR spectroscopy, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The solid-state structure of (3-Me-BnBNHCCH2OxMe)AgCl revealed a linear monomer while [(2,4,6-Me3-BnBNHCCH2OxMe)AgCl]2 was found to exist as a dimer with pseudo trigonal planar geometry about each metal center. The synthesized (RBNHCCH2OxMe)AgX complexes were found to be efficient for the addition of carbon dioxide to epoxides to yield value-added cyclic carbonates at ambient pressure. Amongst the investigated complexes, the bimetallic complex [(2,4,6-Me3-BnBNHCCH2OxMe)AgCl]2 was found to be the most active for CO2 insertion, exhibiting favorable activity when compared to known NHC complexes.
coredata.dc:title: Benzimidazole-based N-heterocyclic carbene silver complexes as catalysts for the formation of carbonates from carbon dioxide and epoxides
